text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This IRM was updated to reﬂect various editorial changes, and the following substantive changes:

IRM Reference Change 5.8.12 This revision contains various editorial changes, updates and grammatical corrections through- out the revision. 5.8.12.1 through 5.8.12.1.6 Added and updated Program Scope and Objectives and its related subsections to comply with the Deputy Commissioners for Services and Enforcement and Operations Support memo, dated September 14, 2016, entitled Heightened Awareness, Sensitivity, and Understanding of Internal Controls. 5.8.12.2 Updated- Notes: Centralized Offer In Compromise (COIC) — The COIC OE must include a complete printout of the latest AOIC Remarks. Field Offer In Compromise — The IAR has the capability to review the current history on ICS; therefore, it is no longer necessary for Field OS to include a copy of the ICS history with the case submission. 5.8.12.3.(1) Removed: Note and incorporated “read receipt” into bullet sentence 5.8.12.3 (3) Updated to include: offer number 5.8.12.3 (1)(B) Removed: Withdrawl
Updated

IRM Reference Change 5.8.12.3 (1) (f) Updated: Rejection summary documented in ICS/AOIC, including all issues not in agreement between the taxpayer and the Offer Examiner (OE) or Offer Specialist (OS) 5.8.12.3 (1) (g) Updated Note: Centralized Offer In Compromise (COIC) — The IAR has the capability to review the current history on AOIC, the COIC OE/SE no longer needs to include a complete printout of the latest AOIC Remarks. 5.8.12.3 (1) (g) Updated Note: Field Offer In Compromise The IAR has the capability to review the current history on ICS; therefore, it is no longer necessary for Field OS to include a copy of the ICS history with the case submission 5.8.12.3 (1) (h) Removed Case History- Added: Special Circumstance supporting documents and/or correspon- dence, including any letters explaining or discussing special circumstances 5.8.12.4 Removed Note: Updated bullet: Forward the form back to the originator via secure messaging Read Receipt to ensure delivery. 5.8.12.5 Added Note: If sending cases, use a trackable method such as UPS Ground, FED Ex, etc. include the complete address on the appropriate mailing labels. The complete address and tracking information should appear on both the package, as well as on Document Transmittal Form 3210.

Added Note: If sending cases, use a trackable method such as UPS Ground, FED Ex, etc. include the complete address on the appropriate mailing labels. The complete address tracking information should appear on both the package, as well as on Document Transmittal Form

IRM Reference Change 5.8.12.7.1 (1) Updated (c) Update AOIC to reﬂect the results of the completed review. The Field IAR must document the results of the review on ICS and complete the disposition of the assigned Other Investigation. Removed: (d) and (e) 5.8.12.7.1. (2) Updated and Added: If a physical ﬁle is to be returned to the OE/SE or OS, the Form 3210 must be used. If sending cases, use a trackable method such as UPS Ground, FED Ex, etc. include the complete address on the appropriate mailing labels. The complete address and tracking information should appear both on the package as well as on Document Transmittal Form 3210. (3) If the case is closed using EOIC, follow proce- dures in IRM 5.8.12.3.1, Independent Administrative Review Procedure for EOIC (Field Only) above. (4) Once the signed, approved Form 1271 is received from the IAR, the OE/SE or OS must include a copy in the case ﬁle.

Table of Contents
Purpose: This chapter explains the procedures to be followed by an Indepen- dent Administrative Reviewer on rejected Offer in Compromise:
This IRM provides instruction to conduct an independent review of a proposal to reject an Offer In Compromise in accordance IRC §
). The review must be conducted prior to the ﬁnal determination of the rejection being communicated to the taxpayer. See IRM

The Decision. The purpose of the review is to evaluate the case and determine if rejection was the correct decision. The Independent Administrative Reviewer (IAR) is responsible for conducting this review.
rejection was the correct decision. The Independent Administrative Reviewer (IAR) is responsible for conducting this review. (
) Audience: Independent Administrative Reviewers (IAR) are the primary of this IRM. (
) Policy Owner: Director, Collection Policy, SB/SE is the owner of the this IRM. (
) Program Owner: Collection Policy – Offer In Compromise, an within SB/SE, is responsible for the administration, procedures, and related to the program. (
) Primary Stakeholders: The primary stakeholders are Centralized Offer In Compromise OE/ SE and Field (OS) offer employees for these (

) Program Goals: When the determination is made to reject an Offer In promise application, the proposed rejection must ﬁrst be reviewed by the Independent Administrative Reviewer (IAR). By following the procedures in IRM, IARs will be able to accurately determine whether the proposed is reasonable, and process the proposed rejection appropriately. (
) The Secretary of the Treasury is granted broad authority to compromise liabilities in IRC Section §

), delegates the Commissioner’s authority to accept, reject, terminate, or knowledge withdrawals of offers. (
) The Director, Collection Policy is responsible for all policies and within the Offer in Compromise program. (
) The National Program Manager, Offer in Compromise is responsible for opment and delivery of policies and procedures within the program. (
) IRM authors are responsible for writing the policies and procedures and clearing documents through all affected offices. (
) Offer examiners, offer specialists, and other employees rejecting offers are sponsible for processes and procedures in this IRM.
Primary Stakeholders: The primary stakeholders are Centralized Offer In Compromise OE/ SE and Field (OS) offer employees for these procedures.

) Operational and program reviews are conducted on a yearly basis by the Director, Specialty Offers in Compromise (SOIC) and Collection Policy use of data and reports from the Automated Offer in Compromise system ENTITY case management system. In addition, ad hoc reports, which information on the inventory levels, hours per case, and age of offers in inventory or at time of closure, are also provided. See IRM
, Guide for Managers, Offer in Compromise Manager’s Resource Guide - Program and IRM
, Offer in Compromise Manager’s - Centralized Program Guide. (
) Managerial case reviews are also completed as deﬁned in IRM

, Offer in Compromise Manager’s - tralized OIC Program Guide. (
) National quality reviews and consistency reviews are routinely conducted ensure case actions are timely and in accordance with the procedures in IRM. (

) AOIC is used to track offers submitted by taxpayers and record case and history. Ability to take action on AOIC is limited to speciﬁc offer Additional permissions are provided based on an employee’s duties and sponsibilities. (
) ICS is used by ﬁeld employees as a method for inventory control and documentation. (
) Managers are required to follow program management procedures and controls addressed in IRM
, Resource Guide for Managers, Offer in Compromise Manager’s Resource Guide - Field Program and IRM
, Offer in Compromise Manager’s - Centralized OIC Program Guide. (

) Common abbreviations, deﬁnitions and acronyms used throughout this AET Asset Equity Table – A table listing all the taxpayers assets, encumbrances, and exemptions. It then calcu- lates the equity which is included in the reasonable collection potential (RCP) calculation. AOIC Automated Offer in Compromise – Computer application where offers in compromise are recorded and monitored from receipt to closure. History of the offer investigations conducted by COIC employees and of actions taken by Monitoring OIC (MOIC) units are also maintained on this system.

AET Asset Equity Table – A table listing all the taxpayers assets, encumbrances, and exemptions. It then calcu

lates the equity which is included in the reasonable collection potential (RCP) calculation. AOIC Automated Offer in Compromise – Computer application where offers in compromise are recorded and monitored from receipt to closure. History of the offer investigations conducted by COIC employees and of actions taken by Monitoring OIC (MOIC) units are also maintained on this system.

) As an alternative method of submitting documents to the IAR for review, it is recommended that the OS use secured e-mail attachments instead of physi- cally shipping the case ﬁle. This method should result in considerable savings of time and shipping costs while eliminating the possibility of loss of the case ﬁle in transit.
Note: All documents transmitted by e-mail must be sent using Secure Messaging.
he scanned documents must be reduced to a PDF ﬁle for transmittal to the IAR as an e-mail attachment, with Scanned Documents XXXX (last
digits of SSN) and offer number

The XXXX in the subject line will be the last 4 digits of the Taxpayer cation Number (TIN) or Employee Identiﬁcation Number (EIN) and the offer number. Use the PDF format that yields the smallest ﬁle size.

Note: Field Offer In Compromise — The IAR has the capability to review the current history on ICS; therefore, it is no longer necessary for Field OS to include a copy of the ICS history with the case submission. h. Special Circumstance supporting documents and/or correspondence, including any letters explaining or discussing special circumstances. (

) If the IAR determines that any information is missing or incomplete that may hinder the review process, the case ﬁle may be returned or a memorandum may be sent to the OE, OS, or the manager requesting the information. Note: In cases where the IAR is located off-site, the requested information may faxed or electronically submitted via e-mail to the IAR for inclusion in the analysis. See IRM

) If the Field OS follows procedures in IRM
, Transmission of Using the Electronic Offer in Compromise (EOIC) Process (Field Only) and
, Independent Administrative Review Procedure for EOIC (Field above, the “Read Receipt” on Outlook must be used. (
) The Field IAR will load the case onto ICS no later than seven (
) calendar days after receipt. (
) The IAR will be responsible for updating AOIC to reﬂect the IAR’s number. (
) The IAR should complete the review and reach a determination no later thirty (
) calendar days from opening the ICS OI or assignment on AOIC. (

) Upon completion of the review, the IAR must update AOIC documenting mation on the results of the review. In addition, the Field IAR must the results of the review on ICS and complete the disposition of the Other Investigation(OI). (
) The results of the review should be communicated in a clear, concise, sional and easy to understand manner. (
) The OE or OS analysis of the taxpayer’s OIC should be reviewed to if the basis for the rejection determination was appropriate. (

) The IAR should consider if the taxpayer’s rights have been observed during the offer investigation, in communications, and/or discussions with the or Power of Attorney (POA). These considerations should be based on that would impact the recommended rejection. (

) When reviewing a doubt as to collectability offer, the IAR should compare offered amount with the RCP in order to determine if the decision to reject reasonable. Review the Asset/Equity Table, the Income/Expense Table IET), and the taxpayer’s ﬁnancial information to determine if the reasonable collection potential (RCP) determination is fully supported by the facts and circumstances in the case ﬁle; including making sure the OE/OS fully developed the RCP and discussed all issues with the taxpayer before ommending the rejection. Note: It is not the responsibility of the IAR to re-work the case; however, it is the responsibility of the IAR to make sure all aspects of the offer have been taken into consideration.
The IAR should complete the review and reach a determination no later than thirty (30) calendar days from opening the ICS OI or assignment on AOIC.
The OE or OS analysis of the taxpayer’s OIC should be reviewed to determine if the basis for the rejection determination was appropriate.

) If supporting documents indicate any circumstances that could impact either future earning potential or allowable expenses, the documentation in the case ﬁle must support the decision to exclude or include assets, expenses and/or income relating to the taxpayer’s circumstances. (

) If information contained in the case ﬁle indicates issues were raised that meet either Effective Tax Administration (ETA) or Doubt as to Collectibility Special Circumstance (DCSC) criteria, as deﬁned in IRM
, Effective Tax Adminis- tration, the case history must address these issues as well as support the rejection decision.
Review

Note: It is not a requirement that the taxpayer speciﬁcally ask for consideration “special circumstances.” If the IAR identiﬁes the existence of special stances that meet ETA or DCSC criteria, this fact should be addressed. IAR should be alert to instances of Payroll Service Provider Fraud for ETA Special Circumstance consideration and review the victim’s individual circumstances. (

) The IAR should ensure that all of the facts and circumstances of the case were considered during the investigation and that the decision to reject the offer is reasonable, based on the case analysis. (

) The case ﬁle should indicate an attempt to communicate the results of the investigation with the taxpayer or POA, prior to recommending the rejection. The IAR should determine whether the communications were reasonable based on the facts of the case. Note: Communications may not necessarily be telephone calls. In some cases, they may be conducted entirely in the form of letters to the taxpayer or authorized representative. The case ﬁle should document these tions and any speciﬁc issues that are in dispute. (
) When circumstances dictate, the OE/OS should use problem solving and fessional judgment, and in so doing, consider the taxpayer’s perspective working toward case resolution. (
) The below sections provide closing actions for the IAR based on whether decision to reject the offer was appropriate. (
) If the proposed rejection of the offer is sustained by the IAR, the reviewer a. Update the IAR “Main Screen” on AOIC indicating the appropriate sition. b. Sign the Form

as the reviewer, indicating concurrence with the proposed disposition. c. Update AOIC to reﬂect the results of the completed review. The Field must document the results of the review on ICS and complete the sition of the assigned Other Investigation. (
) If a physical ﬁle is to be returned to the OE/SE or OS, the Form

a. Update the IAR “Main Screen” on AOIC indicating the appropriate disposition. b. Prepare the Form

Independent Administrative Review

If… Then… After a second review by the IAR, The decision will be elevated to the rejection is still not sustained the second level manager for and if the OE/SE/OS and the IAR resolution. still disagree • The IAR manager will forward a memorandum to the Offer Manager with an explanation of why the rejection cannot be sustained. • A copy of the memoran- dum will be forwarded to the second level manager. • The IAR manager and the second level manager will discuss the issues to reach a resolution. • The ﬁnal decision will be made by the ﬁeld second level manager for cases assigned to the ﬁeld and the second level manager for those cases decided by the COIC sites.
The original Form 5942 and any other documentation regarding second level management involvement and decisions must be retained in the offer ﬁle as a record of actions taken during the IAR process.
